Silver nano-particles (AgNPs) are widely used in a range of consumer products as a result of their antimicrobial properties. Given the broad spectrum of uses, AgNPs have the potential for being released to the environment. As a result, environmental risks associated with AgNPs need to be assessed to aid in the development of regulatory guidelines. Research was performed to assess the effects of AgNPs on soil microbial activity and diversity in a sandy loam soil with an emphasis on using a battery of microbial tests involving multiple endpoints. The test soil was spiked with PVP coated (0.3%) AgNPs at the following concentrations of 49, 124, 287, 723 and 1815 mg Ag kg 1 dry soil. Test controls included an unamended soil; soil amended with PVP equivalent to the highest PVP concentration of the coated AgNP; and soil amended with humic acid, as 1.8% humic acid was used as a suspension agent for the AgNPs. The impact on soil microbial community was assessed using an array of tests including heterotrophic plate counting, microbial respiration, organic matter decomposition, soil enzyme activity, biological nitrification, community level physiological profiling (CLPP), Ion Torrent™ DNA sequencing and denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE). An impact on microbial growth, activity and community diversity was evident from 49 to 1815 mg kg 1 with the median inhibitory concentrations (IC50) as low as 20 e31 mg kg 1 depending on the test. AgNP showed a notable impact on microbial functional and genomic diversity. Emergence of a silver tolerant bacterium was observed at AgNP concentrations of 49 e287 mg kg 1 after 14e28 days of incubation, but not detectable at 723 and 1815 mg kg 1. The bacterium was identified as Rhodanobacter sp. The study highlighted the effectiveness of using multiple microbial endpoints for inclusion to the environmental risk assessment of nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Silver nano-particles (AgNPs) are widely used in a range of consumer products including medical, textile and food packaging industries due to their antimicrobial and antiviral properties (Benn et al., 2010; Marambio-Jones and Hoek, 2010; Peyrot et al., 2014; Siripattanakul-Ratpukdi and Fürhacker, 2014; Quadros et al., 2013). The presence of AgNPs in a wide range of consumables increases their likelihood of being released to the environment through wastewater treatment facilities (Nowack et al., 2012;

It has been suggested that the most likely route of AgNPs entering the environment is through the application of biosolids to agriculture lands (Benn and Weterhoff, 2008; Colman et al., 2014; Holden et al., 2014; Langdon et al., 2014; Mueller and Nowack, 2008; Nowack et al., 2012; Siripattanakul-Ratpukdi and Fürhacker, 2014). In North America, nearly half of the biosolids produced are applied to farmlands as agricultural fertilizers (Starnes et al., 2015; U.S. EPA, 1999), with measured concentrations ranging from 2 to 856 mg kg 1 on a dry weight basis (Kim et al., 2010). The broad spectrum of uses, increased presence in consumer products and their potential release to the environment raise the concern that AgNPs may be a burden to terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems, and are thus considered an emerging pollutant (Colman et al., 2013; Kim et al., 2010; Lowry et al., 2012; Yu et al., 2014). Moreover, AgNPs are one of the priority

nanomaterials for environmental and human health risk assessment identified by the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Working Party on Nanomaterials (WPNM) (OECD, 2010).
Silver in its' ionic (Agþ) and nano forms have exhibited toxicity to soil microorganisms and other soil dwelling organisms (Holden et al., 2014; Schlich and Hund-Rinke, 2015; Van der Ploeg et al., 2014; Velicogna et al., 2016). Many studies have looked into the microbial toxicity of AgNPs and there are numerous hypotheses developed based on these studies. The proposed mechanisms of antimicrobial properties of AgNPs have been mostly attributed to the dissolved silver ions (Agþ) from AgNPs (Levard et al., 2012; Marambio-Jones and Hoek, 2010). In addition, toxicity specific to AgNP, due to the physical interaction of AgNPs with microorganisms (Lok et al., 2006; Lubick 2008; Siripattanakul-Ratpukdi and Fürhacker, 2014), and the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) (Yang et al., 2013) have also been reported.
Although the mode of action of AgNPs and associated toxicants on bacteria are not fully elucidated, the suggested pathways of exerting toxicity include changes in cell membrane permeability and redox cycling in the cytosol, disruption of ATP synthesis, oxidative stress due to accumulation of free radicles, and interfering with DNA and protein synthesis (Franci et al., 2015; Lok et al., 2006; Marambio-Jones and Hoek, 2010; McShan et al., 2014; Reidy et al., 2013; Siripattanakul-Ratpukdi and Fürhacker, 2014). Recent studies have shown that AgNPs released into the environment through waste water treatment plants (WWTP) do not retain their pristine physico-chemical properties but transform to silver sulphide (Ag2S) or interact with other sulfhydryl compounds (Colman et al., 2013; Ma et al., 2013; Kaegi et al., 2013; Pradas del Real et al., 2016). This transformation would make them less bioavailable to living organisms (Pradas del Real et al., 2016; Doolette et al., 2013; Kim et al., 2010; Levard et al., 2013). As such, AgNPs released to the environment through WWTP would be expected to behave differently compared to the pristine form. In addition, soil physicochemical properties, such as organic matter, may also contribute to a lessened impact of AgNPs on the terrestrial soil environment (Cornelis et al., 2012; Pradas del Real et al., 2016; Langdon et al., 2014).
The soil microbial community is considered to be an important target for assessing the impact of manufactured nanomaterials on the terrestrial environment (Holden et al., 2014). It has been reported that soil microbial endpoints, including soil enzyme activities (Peyrot et al., 2014), biological nitrification (Langdon et al., 2014; Jeong et al., 2014; Masrahi et al., 2014), and microbial diversity (Shah et al., 2014; Yang et al., 2014b) are impacted by AgNPs. However, a broader range of microbial endpoints have not been considered in research protocols (Holden et al., 2014), nor within regulations for the environmental risk assessments of nanomaterials or other metal contaminants (European Chemical Agency, 2014). Moreover, studies performed with multiple endpoints over extended periods of time are lacking in general for microbial processes, in particular for the assessment of AgNPs in the terrestrial environment. Therefore, this study was undertaken to assess the effect of AgNPs on multiple endpoints, including soil microbial growth, activity and community diversity in a sandy loam soil. The evaluation was performed using PVP (polyvinylpyrrolidone) coated (0.3%) pristine AgNPs, with test concentrations ranging from the low to high spectrum of measured concentrations to capture the extent of effects demonstrated by the multiple endpoints (e.g., growth, activity, diversity) evaluated. The use of a pristine AgNP enabled the evaluation of toxicity, using the battery of microbial tests, but also serves as a baseline for further studies evaluating the effects of AgNP with a biosolidamended soil system.

sections.heading: 2.1. Soil preparation and chemical analysis for AgNP spiked soils
sections.text:
A sandy loam soil (0e15 cm) collected from a site near Vulcan, Alberta, Canada was used in this study. The soil was air-dried for one day, sieved (2 mm) and stored at 4 C until the experiment was performed. The physical and chemical characteristics of the soil are listed in Table A.1 (Supplementary Information). Silver nanoparticles (NanoAmor, New Mexico, USA) used in this study were PVP coated (0.3%) and had an average diameter of 20 nm. The nominal concentrations of AgNPs tested were 60, 145, 347, 833 and 2000mg Ag kg 1 dry soil, and were based on preliminary testing in order to elucidate toxic effects across multiple endpoints of interest. Three controls were included in the experiment: an unamended soil (Con-0), soil amended with PVP equivalent to the PVP content of the highest concentration of AgNPs tested (ConPVP), and soil amended with humic acid (HA). Humic acid (1.8%) was used as a suspension agent as previous research demonstrated that humic acid served as a suitable dispersing agent for amendment of AgNP into soil (Velicogna et al., 2016), given that it represents a natural component of soil and biosolids (Hernandez et al., 1988). AgNPs were suspended in a volume of HA that was required to hydrate test soils to 40% of the soil's maximum water holding capacity (WHC). Using aseptic techniques, the suspension was mixed into the soil with an electric hand mixer; for the Con-0 and Con-PVP control treatments, the soil moisture was adjusted with sterilized water, and mixed accordingly. The AgNP treatments were prepared at the beginning of the experiments, after which test measurements were conducted over time.
The test soils were mixed as three individual batches in order to satisfy the soil test requirements for the seven different microbial assays. Once prepared, the test soils were incubated for 49e63 days at 20 C in the dark, and sub-samples were taken for analysis at 7e14 day intervals, unless otherwise mentioned. The soil pH showed a slight increase with increasing AgNP concentration (5.54 ± 0.03 to 5.87 ± 0.01).
Soils were analysed for total Ag after spiking (before incubation) to assess the homogeneity of each mixing event. Total Ag content was analysed using hot HNO3 digestion followed by ICP-MS analysis (Environmental Chemistry Laboratory, McGill University, Montr eal, QC, Canada). A well-correlated (r2 0.98) linear relationship was derived between the measured and nominal concentrations (Supplementary Information-Fig A.1). The measured concentrations corresponding to the nominal concentrations were pooled across the three batches (49, 124, 287, 723 and 1815 mg Ag kg 1) and are used for the presentation of results. The suspension of AgNP-HA was characterized by measuring particle hydrodynamic diameter and zeta potential by dynamic light scattering (DLS) (Malvern, Zetasizer nano); particle size and agglomerationwas also determined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM-EDS) (FEI, Technai™, G2 F20). The mean diameter measured by DLS and TEM were 65.0 nm and 30.1 nm respectively (n ¼ 3). Details of the analyses have been presented in Velicogna et al. (2016).

Heterotrophic plate counts (HPC) were performed on 10% LB (Luria Bertani-Miller, Fisher Scientific, NJ, USA) agar in triplicate. Three grams of test soil (dry weight) were inoculated into 27 mL (1:10 dilution) of phosphate saline buffer (PBS). Samples were shaken at 200 rpm with twenty sterile glass beads (4 mm) for 10 min at 20 C followed by 10 fold serial dilutions in phosphate buffered saline. Appropriate dilutions were plated on 10% LB agar

and the plates incubated at 20 C for seven days. Colony counts were enumerated 5e7 days after incubation; however, the final counts were based on the 7th day of incubation. The counts were reported as colony forming units (CFU) per gram of soil (dry weight). Sampling was done in 7e14 day intervals.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Microbial respiration (basal and substrate induced respiration)
sections.text:
Basal respiration (BR) testing was based on ISO 16072 and ISO 17155 methods (International Standards Organization, 2002a and 2002b). Briefly, on sampling days, one gram of pre-incubated test soil (dry weight) was added to 20 mL glass vials prepared for four incubation periods (0, 4, 6 and 24 h of incubation), which were then capped with rubber septa and crimp sealed using a Wheaton EZCrimper™ (Fisher Scientific). The vial headspace was sampled destructively at four time points by removing 1 mL of headspace from each vial with a 1 mL airtight syringe (Sample-Lok™ A-2 gas syringe, Sigma-Aldrich, Canada). The BR test was done in triplicate with two technical replicates for each time point totalling six measurements for each time point of individual treatment concentration. The headspace sample (1 mL) was injected into a CO2/ H2O analyzer (LI-840A CO2/H2O Analyzer, Li-COR inc., Lincoln, NE, USA). The time and resulting observed peaks were recorded to calculate rate of CO2 released per gram of soil. Sampling was done in 7e14 day intervals.
The substrate induced respiration (SIR) method was based on ISO 17155 (International Standards Organization, 2002a). Briefly, a required quantity of pre-incubated soil was mixed with glucose (mixed with talcum in 1:4 ratio) at a concentration of 3430mg kg 1 of soil. One gram (dry weight) of the glucose amended soil was added to 20 mL glass vials prepared for four incubation periods (0, 2, 4 and 6 h of incubation), which were then capped and incubated at 20 C. The vial headspace was sampled destructively at four time points on each sampling day by removing 1 mL of headspace from each vial with a 1mL airtight syringe. The content of CO2 released in the BR and SIR tests was calculated as mg C-CO2 hr 1 g 1 of dry soil. The replication and the sampling intervals were the same as for the BR test.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Organic matter decomposition
sections.text: Amodifiedmethod of Knacker et al. (2004) was used to evaluate the rate of organic matter decomposition (OM) in test soils; the modified method was developed and has been validated in-house for various soils and contaminants (Rahn, 2012). Test units were set up by adding 10 g of test soil (dry weight) to 50-mL (Falcon™, Fisher Scientific) conical centrifuge tubes, and then tapping the tube gently to allow the first layer of soil to settle. A pre-weighed disk (25 mm in diameter) of sterile filter paper (09-790-12G, Fisher Scientific) was then added to the top of the soil using sterile forceps. Another 10 g (dry weight) was added on top of the filter paper and again the tube was tapped gently to allow the soil to settle. The test was designed with five replicates for each sampling. Test units were incubated in the dark at 20 C in an incubator for 112 days. Test moisture within the vessels was maintained on a weekly basis based on changes in mass. Test vessels were destructively sampled such that the filter paper disks and any adhering soil particles were carefully removed using fine paint brushes and water. The filter papers were then dried at 105 C for 24 h, after which the percentage mass remaining was calculated. Sampling was done in 14e21 day intervals.

sections.text:
2.3.3.1. Dehydrogenase assay. Dehydrogenase activity was

determined according to Garcia et al. (1997) with some modifications (Klose et al., 2006). One gram of test soil amended with glucose (16 mg g 1 of soil, finely ground and mixed with talcum powder (1:3 on weight basis)) was mixed with 0.2 mL solution of 0.4% INT (2-p-iodophenyl-3-p-nitrophenyl-5-phenyltetrazolium chloride) (Sigma-Aldrich, MO, USA) and incubated for 20 h at 22 C in the dark. Treatment blanks were prepared with 0.2 mL of sterilized water in place of INT and were incubated along with INT treated samples. The INTF (iodo-nitrotetrazolium formazan) formed was extracted with 10 mL of methanol by shaking vigorously for 1 min and filtering through a Whatman No. 5 filter paper (GE Healthcare Limited, Bukinghamshire, UK). The blanks were also extracted similarly. The INTF was measured spectrophotometrically at 490 nm using an Evolution 201 UVevisible spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific, MA, USA). A standard curve was used to determine the concentration of INTF produced due to the reduction of INT corresponding to an absorbance measurement. The assay was done in triplicates.
2.3.3.2. b-glucosidase and phosphatase assays. Glucosidase and phosphatase activities were determined according to the methods described by Saiya-Cork et al. (2002) and Weintraub et al. (2007) with some modifications. Fluorescently-labelled substrates, 4- MUB-b-D-glucoside and 4-MUB-phosphate (Sigma-Aldrich), and a fluorescent standard, 4-methylumbelliferone (MUB) (SigmaAldrich), were used. Briefly, 1 g of test soil (dry weight) was suspended in 100 mL of sodium phosphate buffer (pH 5.5) and homogenized using a tissue homogenizer (Polytron PT 1300D, Kinematica Ag, Bohemia, NY, USA) at 13,000 rpm. Two hundred microliters of resultant soil homogenatewas added to eachwell of a black 96-well plate (VWR International, Mississauga, ON, Canada) and buffer, substrate and standard were added as required. Plates were incubated at 20 C in the dark for 2 h. Immediately prior to reading, 10 mL of 0.5 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH) was added to each well of the fluorescence plate to stop the reaction. Plates were read immediately at 365 nm excitation and 460 nm emission on a FLx800 multi-well Spectrofluorometer (Biotek, Winooski, VT, USA). The assay was done in triplicates.
2.3.4. Nitrification Nitrification in soil was assessed using a method adapted from the Organization for Economic Development (OECD) guideline for measuring nitrification in soil (OECD, 2000). Powdered alfalfa meal (Legal Alfalfa Products Ltd, Legal, Alberta, Canada) was used as the substrate. Alfalfa was mixed with AgNP amended soils and control soils at a rate of 5 mg alfalfa per gram of soil (dry weight) followed by mixing using a hand mixer. The soil was then incubated at 20 C and sampled at 7e14 day intervals; the test soils were incubated for 84 days as we observed that the effects were more pronounced over time. On each sampling day, soil was extracted with 0.1 M KCl (5 mL of KCl per gram of dry soil) by shaking at 150 rpm for 60 min at 20 C. Extracts were filtered using a 90 mm (diameter) Whatman No. 41 ashless filter paper (Fisher Scientific) under vacuum. Filtrates were stored at 20 C until analysed for NO3 using an Astoria 2 segmented flow analyzer (Astoria-Pacific, Clackamas, OR, USA) as per themanufacturer's instructions. Nitrate productionwas calculated by subtracting day-zero NO3 concentrations from subsequent sampling times. The assay was performed in triplicates.

sections.text:

2.4.1. Community level physiological profiling (CLPP) Community Level Physiological Profiling (CLPP) was performed using 96-well Biolog Ecoplates ™ that contain 31 different carbon sources in three replicates and a control well (Biolog, Hayward, CA, USA). Three grams of test soil (dry weight) were added to 27 mL of sterile water (1:10 dilution) in a 250 mL Nalgene bottle (Fisher Scientific) with 20 glass beads (3 mm diameter) and shaken at 200 rpm for 10 min at 20 C. The suspension was serially diluted to obtain a 100-fold (1:100) working solution. The resultant solution was shaken vigorously for 30s using a vortex and then left to settle for 45 min. One hundred microliters of the solution was then inoculated into each well followed by incubation of the plates at 20 C. Color development was measured by reading the Eco-plates ™ using a spectrophotometer (Power Wave XS, Biotek, Winooski, VT, USA) on days 5, 6, and 7; however, the final calculations were performed based on the day 7 reading. The color development was recorded as average well color development (AWCD) and is defined as:
AWCD ¼ X ODi=31
where ODi is the optical density (OD) for each well, corrected by subtracting the OD of the blank well (inoculated but without a carbon source) from each plate well. The number (31) represents the number of wells with different carbon substrates.

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Ion Torrent™ sequencing
sections.text: Total genomic DNA (gDNA) was extracted from 0.5 g of control and AgNP spiked soils (49, 124, 287, 723, and 1815 mg Ag kg 1) in triplicates using the PowerSoil DNA Isolation Kit (MoBio Laboratories Inc., CA, USA) following the manufacturer's instructions. The V2, V3, V4, V6,7,V8 and V9 hypervariable regions of 16S rRNA genes of the bacteria were amplified by the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) using 50e100 ng mL 1 of template gDNA from each treatment following the instructions provided in the Ion 16S Metagenomics Kit (Life Technologies, Carlsbad, CA, USA - Cat No. A26216.). PCR amplicons from each treatment were modified by the nick repair followed by the fusion of PGM sequencing adaptors using the Ion Plus Fragment Library Kit (Life Technologies, Cat No. 4471252) and unique Ion Xpress barcodes (Life Technologies, Cat No. 4471250) according to the manufacturer's instructions. All PCR products before and after adapter and barcode ligation were purified using Agencourt® AMPure XP beads (Beckman Coulter Genomics, MA, USA) and checked for size and specificity by electrophoresis on 1.0% w/v agarose gel. After purification, the products were quantified by a Bioanalyzer (Agilent® 2100, Agilent Technologies, CA, USA) using Agilent® High Sensitivity 1000 DNA kit (Agilent Technologies, CA, USA). The emulsion PCRwas performed using an Ion OneTouch 400 Template Kit (Life Technologies) followed by enrichment of Ion Sphere Particles (ISPs) using the OneTouch ES instrument (Life Technologies) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The sequencing was performed using an Ion Torrent™ PGM (Life Technologies), PGM™ Sequencing 400 Kit (Life Technologies), and Torrent-Suite software (version 4.2.1).

sections.heading: 2.4.3. Denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE)
sections.text:
Universal primers specific for 16S rDNA, F984 (968e984) 50- AACGCGAAGAACCTTAC-30 and R1378 Bacteria (1378e1401), 50- CGGTGTGTACAAGGCCCGGGAACG-30 (Novinscak et al., 2009) were

used to PCR amplify a 440 bp segment of the V6-V8 region of 16S rDNA, using the DNA extracted as stipulated in the preceding section. The forward primer, F984, was fused with a 40 bp GC clamp (50-CGCCCGGGGCGCGCCCCGGGCGGGGCGGGGGCACGGGGGG-30). The PCR reaction mixture contained 1 reaction buffer, 1.5 mmol L 1 MgCl2, 0.5 mmol L 1 of each primer, 200 mmol L 1 of dNTP, 1.25 units of Taq DNA polymerase and sterile ddH2O in a final volume of 25 mL. The PCR cycling protocol consisted of an initial denaturation at 94 C for 5 min followed by 35 cycles of denaturation at 94 C for 1 min, annealing at 55 C for 1 min and extension at 72 C for 2 min followed by a final extension at 72 C for 5 min. The resulting 16S rDNA PCR amplicons were used for DGGE analysis using the DCode Universal Mutation Detection system (Bio-Rad, USA). DGGE analysis was performed with 8% polyacrylamide (m/v) gels in 1 Tris/acetate/EDTA (TAE) buffer. Optimum separation was achieved with a 35e70% (100% corresponds to 7 M urea and 40% (weight/vol) deionized formamide) urea and formamide linear gradient. Gels were electrophoresed at a constant voltage of 75 V at 62 C for 17 h followed by staining with SYBR Safe (Invitrogen, Eugene, OR) for 45 minwith shaking at 45 rpm using the Orbit™ LS low speed shaker (Labnet International Inc, NJ, USA). The gels were imaged with an Alpha Imager ™ 2200 system (Alpha innotech, CA, USA). The distinct DGGE bands were excised using sterile gel extraction tools (BioLynx Inc, Brockville, ON, Canada) and eluted in sterile water overnight at 4 C. One mL of the solution was used as template to re-amplify the band fragment using the same primers without the GC clamp under the same PCR conditions mentioned above. rDNA amplicons of excised gel bands were cloned using the TOPO TA Cloning kit (Invitrogen, Eugene, RO) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Transformed cells were plated on LB agar (Fisher Scientific) with 50 mgmL 1 Kanamycin (Sigma-Aldrich) and incubated at 37 C. Representative colonies from clonal libraries corresponding to the excised gel bands were randomly picked and grown overnight in LB liquid medium with 50 mg mL 1 Kanamycin. The clones were submitted to Beckman Coulter Genomics for one directional sequencing with a T7 primer.

sections.heading: 2.5. Statistical analysis
sections.text:
A repeated measure ANOVA (RM ANOVA) using SPSS (SPSS Inc. Chicago IL, version 24) was employed to test for treatment effects versus incubation time. Parametric ANOVA assumptions of homogeneity of variance and test for normality of distributions were verified using Levene's test and Shapiro-Wilk's test respectively. Data were validated using Mauchly's sphericity test and in cases where the assumption of sphericity was not met, a GreenhouseGeisser correction was used to adjust the degrees of freedom. When interactions of treatment versus incubation time were significant, Bonferroni-adjusted simple main effects within time points were assessed.
Concentrationeresponse relationships were analysed using SYSTAT (version 13). Data from selected test endpoints were fitted to concentration-response curves to determine the concentrations leading to a 50% inhibitive effect (IC50) (Environment Canada, 2005). For concentration-response curves that showed a significant hormetic effect (p < 0.05) at low AgNP concentrations, a nonlinear hormetic regression model was fitted (Environment Canada, 2005). The toxicity estimates were calculated based on the microbial toxicity data obtained on day 14 of the incubation of test soil (before the emergence of silver tolerant bacteria), except for the OM decomposition test (day 56) which required a comparatively longer incubation period. The toxicity estimates for biological nitrification was calculated on day 28 based on the OECD test protocol (OECD, 2000).
Sequence data were analysed using the Ion Reporter

Sequence alignment was performed using the built-in curated reference data base, Greengenes and MicroSEQ® in the Reporter™ Software. The parameters used for sequence alignment included, the minimum read length after trimming primers (200 bp), the minimum number of reads required (10) and the percentage identity value required to make a genus ID (97%). The Shannon diversity indices (Shannon and Weaver, 1969) were calculated to reflect species richness and evenness of the bacterial community using de-noised taxonomic information obtainedwithMetagenomicworkflow (beta) in the Ion Reporter software™. The sequence data were normalized based on the treatment with the lowest number of reads for the calculation diversity indices.

sections.heading: 3.1. Effect of AgNP on microbial growth, activity and diversity
sections.text:
For the microbial assays, data were measured in 7e14-day intervals; however, only 3e4 time points (depending on the assays) were selected for discussion, based on the observed microbial community shift in the AgNP-amended soil. There were no significant differences among the three control treatments (Con (0), Con
(PVP) and HA) in all but one of the tests: the HA control in the dehydrogenase enzyme assay showed significantly higher activity relative to the other two controls. Despite this, the un-amended control (Con (0)) was used for all treatment comparisons.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Microbial growth
sections.text: Repeated measure analysis on microbial growth data revealed a significant (p < 0.001) interaction between the AgNP treatment and time (Supplementary information-Table A. 3). A post-hoc analysis of the simple main effects showed that microbial growth was significantly (p < 0.001) inhibited at 49mg Ag kg 1 relative to the control one day after incubation (Fig. 1). A similar significant trend was visible on days 14, 35 and 49, with the exception for 124 and 287 mg Ag kg 1. Interestingly, the emergence of a silver tolerant bacterial species (Fig. 1; Supplementary Information-Fig. A.2) was observed at 124 and 287 mg kg 1 after 14 days of incubation; the Ag tolerant species was also shown to emerge at 49 mg kg 1 after 63 days of incubation (data not shown). At high concentrations (i.e., 723 and 1815 mg kg 1), an increase in AgNP toxicity over time was evident, although no Ag tolerant species were detected. Preliminary tests showed that the AgNP concentration of 10 mg kg 1 had no observable toxicity compared to control treatments (data not shown).

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Microbial activity
sections.text:
3.1.2.1. Basal and substrate induced respiration. A significant interaction between concentration and time (P < 0.001) was also evident in both basal (BR) and substrate induced respiration (SIR) (Supplementary information-Table A.3). Post-hoc analysis demonstrated that the soils amended with 124, 287 and 723 mg Ag kg 1 (AgNP) had a significant elevation (p < 0.01) of basal respiration (BR) one day after incubation in comparison to the control (Fig. 2a). There was also a significant reduction (p < 0.05) of BR by day 14 of incubation at 124 mg kg 1. An increasing BR trend was observed at 124 and 287mg kg 1 by day 49, which was most likely due to the emergence of the Ag tolerant bacterium.
The substrate induced respiration (SIR) was shown to be significantly affected (p < 0.01) at concentrations 49 mg kg 1 relative to the control from day one of the incubation and was consistent throughout the experiment (Fig. 2b). The toxicity of AgNPs on SIR was evident with a clear concentration-response relationship such that the 14-day IC50 was 30.3 mg Ag kg 1 (Table 1). Substrate induced respiration was inhibited by 63% relative to the control by day 49.

However, simple main effects showed that there was a significant toxicity of AgNPs even at the first sampling (21 days after incubation) with a comparatively high filter paper mass remaining at 49 mg Ag kg 1 relative to the control (Fig. 3). In general, decomposition steadily increased with time in AgNP amended soil, but the rate of decomposition remained low at 287 mg kg 1 even after 112 days of incubation. In addition, a visible fungal growth was detected in test soils treated with AgNPs.
3.1.2.3. Soil enzyme activity. The effect of AgNPs on soil enzymatic processes was determined by evaluating dehydrogenase, b-
glucosidase and acid phosphatase activities. Dehydrogenase, bglucosidase and acid phosphatase activities showed significant interaction between treatment and time (Supplementary information-Table A.3). Dehydrogenase enzyme activity showed the greatest sensitivity to AgNPs with a 14-day IC50 of 19.9 mg Ag kg 1 (Table 1 and Fig. 4a). Based on the analysis of simple main effects, b-glucosidase activity was significantly inhibited at 49 mg kg 1 (p < 0.001) relative to the control as shown on 14 and 56 days of incubation (Fig. 4b). However, acid phosphatase was the least affected enzyme activity throughout all AgNP test concentrations (Supplementary Information-Fig. A.3). In general, the inhibition of enzyme activities correlated with Ag concentrations in the AgNP-amended soil with clear concentration-response relationships. The addition of PVP as a treatment blank had no significant impact on enzyme activities; however, humic acid showed a significantly higher dehydrogenase activity compared to the blank and control treatment (data not shown).
3.1.2.4. Biological nitrification. There was a significant interaction between treatment and time (p < 0.001) for nitrification activity (Supplementary information; Table A.3). No significant inhibition of nitrification was visible by day 28; however, there was a significant (p < 0.001) hormetic effect in nitrate production at 49 mg Ag kg 1 (AgNP). The EC50 value on day 28 couldn't be derived as 50% inhibition relative to control couldn't be observed at the highest concentration (1815 mg Ag kg 1). The hormetic effect continued to visible throughout the experimental period at 49 mg kg 1 (Fig. 5). The same effect was visible at 124 mg kg 1 by day 84. A significant inhibition of nitrification was visible by day 84 at >124 mg kg 1 (Fig. 5), indicating that the effect become more pronounced over time. This experiment was continued for 84 days despite the recommended duration of 28 days as the hormetic effect continued to extend from low to moderately high concentrations with toxicity enhanced over time.

The effect of AgNPs on microbial diversity and community structure was assessed using CLPP, DGGE and Ion Torrent™ DNA sequencing. With the CLPP data, average well color development (AWCD) showed a significant interaction (p < 0.001) between treatment and time (Supplementary information-Table A.3). The inhibitory effect of AgNP on functional microbial diversity was clearly visible with CLPP at the lowest test concentration (49 mg kg 1) at each time point (Fig. 6) and with a 14-day IC50 of 31.2 mg Ag kg 1 (Table 1).

The molecular diversity of the bacterial community of AgNPamended soil was assessed using Ion Torrent™ DNA sequencing. The community composition appeared to have been impacted by the increasing concentration of AgNPs in the test soil (Supplementary Information-Fig. A.4). The alpha diversity of the bacterial community, as estimated by the Shannon-Wiener index, was indicative of an adverse impact at low to moderately high concentration of AgNPs (Supplementary Information; Table. sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text: Soil microorganisms play a vital role in soil ecological functions and are considered the key drivers of biological and geological processes (Aislabie and Deslippe, 2013). Recent studies have shown that soil microbial communities are important for assessing the impact of manufactured nanomaterials on the terrestrial environment. Nonetheless, microbial endpoints have not been adequately considered within regulations for the environmental risk assessments of nanomaterials (Holden et al., 2014). In this study, we assessed the effects of pristine AgNPs on a soil microbial community by examining multiple endpoints from a battery of microbial tests representative of microbial growth, activity and diversity. This study revealed that soil microbial diversity and function were affected; however, the impact on microbial diversity was more pronounced with the emergence of a Ag tolerant bacterium at low to moderately high AgNP concentrations (49e287 mg Ag kg 1). Although there was an indication of bacterial resiliency in the presence of AgNPs, no clear evidence showed that this resiliency contributed to functional redundancy in AgNP amended soil, except in the OM decomposition test. Given the importance of microbial structure on ecosystem functions, the microbial test battery was able to assess both microbial structure and function. Pristine AgNPs were used in this study as a test material for preliminary screening; however, current literature has indicated that AgNPs released to the environment are presumably transformed to Ag2S or complexed with a sulfhydryl compound in a WWTP (Cornelis et al., 2012; Ma et al., 2013; Pradas del Real et al., 2016). In fact, it is anticipated that the transformed compound would have a lesser impact on living organisms relative to the pristine form (Levard et al., 2013). For the purpose of this study, however, pristine AgNPs were used to generate baseline information for subsequent research studies.

sections.heading: 4.1. Effects AgNPs on microbial growth
sections.text:
This study showed that exposure to AgNPs in soil negatively affected microbial growth over a concentration range of 49e1815 mg Ag kg 1 while also inducing the emergence of a silver tolerant bacterium (Supplementary Information-Fig. A.2). Silver nanoparticles may exert toxicity on soil microorganisms through multiple modes of action. These toxic effects can be due to dissolved Agþ, AgNP-specific effects, or oxidative stress due to the exogenous or endogenous production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) (i.e. superoxide or hydroxyl radicals) (Levard et al., 2012; Lok et al., 2006; Lubick, 2008; Marambio-Jones and Hoek, 2010; Mohanty et al., 2014; Siripattanakul-Ratpukdi and Fürhacker, 2014; Xiu et al., 2012). Unfortunately, determining the mechanisms of toxicity was beyond the scope of this research. As observed in this study, the toxicity of AgNPs on soil organisms is dose-dependent and that observed toxicity can depend on soil physico-chemical characteristics (Schlich and Hund-Rinke, 2015; Hansch and Emmerling, 2010).
Emergence of the Ag tolerant bacterium was a notable observation in this study (Supplementary Information-Fig. A.2 and A.4). Bacterial tolerance to heavy metals is not uncommon (Silver, 1996; Trevors et al., 1985) including silver (Silver, 2003). Metal tolerance of Rhodanobacter strains too are reported in the literature (Chung et al., 2014: Green et al., 2012); however, this is the first demonstrated tolerance of Rhodanobacter sp. to silver. Bacterial metal resistant mechanisms generally include active extrusion of heavy metals by ion efflux systems diminishing the accumulation inside the cell, segregation into complex sulfur-containing molecules, or reduction into less toxic oxidation states (Nies, 1999). resistance in bacteria is often encoded by genes located on plasmids. For example, silver (Agþ) resistance of bacteria is encoded by the plasmid pMG101 (Gupta et al., 2001). The gene cluster on the plasmid contains a total of nine genes which encode three different mechanisms (i.e., a periplasmic metal-binding protein, a chemiosmotic efflux pump and an ATPase efflux pump) to exert resistance to silver (Silver, 2003). Further research on the silver tolerance of Rhodanobacter sp. isolated herein would be well-warranted to further assess the mechanisms behind the observed tolerance.

sections.heading: 4.2. Effects of AgNPs on microbial activity
sections.text:
The potential for AgNPs to alter soil microbial activities (respiration, soil enzyme activities) and ecosystem functions (organic matter decomposition and nitrification) were evident in this study. Basal respiration increased on day 1 at concentrations 723 mg Ag kg 1 but was inhibited thereafter at concentrations greater than 124 mg kg 1 (except for 287 mg kg 1 on day 49). Kumar et al. (2014) reported similar effects where microbial respiration was depressed by approximately 75% in arctic soils amended with AgNPs (6.6% w/w) relative to the control soils. Increased basal respiration on day 1 was likely due to cryptic growth where carbon and nitrogen compounds available from lysed cells were utilised as a substrate by surviving bacteria (Postgate, 1967). Inhibitory effects of AgNPs were more pronounced in SIR. In agreement with our results, Schlich and Hund-Rinke (2015) also reported inhibition of SIR in response to added AgNPs (0.56e15mg kg 1 of soil) in five soil types.
A major component of assessing the impact of a contaminant on soil function is through examining nutrient cycling effects. Therefore, in this study AgNPs are likely to have an impact on nutrient cycling by affecting soil enzyme activities that control nutrient utilization. In comparison to the present study, concentrationdependent inhibition of enzyme activities in AgNP spiked soils has been reported in previous studies (Shin et al., 2012; Engelke et al., 2014). In fact, dehydrogenase activity has been shown to be one of the most sensitive enzymes for metal contamination (Oliveira and Pampulha, 2006). This is evident in the present study by the 85% relative inhibition of dehydrogenase activity to the control at 49 mg kg 1 by day 56. Furthermore, dehydrogenase activity can be linked to microbial respiration and biomass and is considered an indirect measurement of microbial activity and viability (Neto et al., 2007). Dehydrogenase activity is also directly related to the biological oxidation of organic compounds (Ross, 1971) and therefore, its inhibition may have affected the OM decomposition. Similarly to dehydrogenase activity, b-glucosidase activity also plays a major role in OM decomposition and carbon cycling (Stott et al., 2010; Caldwell, 2005). Again, the reduced bglucosidase activity may have contributed to the OM results. Acid phosphatase activity did not show a consistent inhibition in this study except at 1815 mg kg 1; however, Colman et al. (2013) reported 27% reduction in acid phosphatase activity even at 0.14 mg kg 1 of AgNPs.
It has been recognized that high concentrations of heavy metals have an adverse effect on organic matter decomposition (Chaney et al., 1978). Pradhan et al. (2011) reported results for plant litter decomposition in an aquatic system whereby rates of leaf decomposition decreased at 100e300 mg L 1 of AgNPs in streamwater. In contrast, Gitipour et al. (2013) reported that composting of municipal solid wastewas not significantly affected by the presence of AgNPs at relatively low concentrations (2 mg kg 1 total silver); however, they did observe a change in the microbial community structure. According to Gitipour et al. (2013), the most likely factors for not observing toxicity included possible bacterial functional redundancy within the compost samples, the reaction of AgNPs

with organic ligands in the complex composting system, or the availability of high natural organic carbon which may have limited the bioavailability of AgNPs. However, the range of concentrations used in our study was relatively higher than that of Gitipour et al. (2013). In our study, the increased rate of decomposition over time at low to moderate AgNP concentrations (i.e., 145 mg kg 1) could have been attributed to the emergence of the Ag tolerant bacterium or dominance of fungi in the test soil due to their less sensitivity to moderate metal stresses (Hansch and Emmerling, 2010; Pradhan et al., 2011). In fact, we did observe the emergence of fungi in AgNP-amended OM test units over timewhichmay have contributed to the fast decomposition of filter papers in AgNP amended soils.
Inhibitory effects of AgNPs on the nitrification process, andmore specifically ammonia oxidizing bacteria (AOB), have been reported (Beddow et al., 2014; Jeong et al., 2014). Ammonia oxidizing bacteria drive the first rate limiting reaction (i.e., ammonia oxidation) of nitrification and are reported to be highly sensitive to changing environmental conditions and pollutants (Luo et al., 2014; Joye and Hollibaugh,1995; Nicol et al., 2008). Inhibition of nitrification in the presence of AgNPs has been reported in several studies (Choi and Hu, 2009; Choi et al., 2008; Beddow et al., 2014); however, data on AgNP toxicity on nitrification in the terrestrial environment are limited. Studies performed in soil have reported that the degree of suppression of nitrification increased with increasing concentrations of AgNPs (Masrahi et al., 2014). Our study similarly showed that AgNPs in soil have a detrimental effect on nitrification and that these effects tended to be more pronounced with incubation time. It was noted in this study that nitrification was induced (hormetic effect) at a relatively low concentration (49 mg kg 1). Although the reason for hormesis is not known, it did coincide with the emergence of the silver tolerant bacterium. Interestingly, an increase in nitrification up to 2-fold in the presence of low concentrations of Ag (AgNO3) in soil has been reported by Langdon et al. (2014). The concentration range tested in this study was 10e640 mg kg 1 of Ag (AgNO3) and the hormetic responses detected were within similar concentrations to our study.

sections.heading: 4.3. Effects of AgNPs on microbial diversity
sections.text:
Adverse effects upon exposure of AgNPs on the microbial community structure have been reported in diverse environments including terrestrial, aquatic, marine and wastewater systems (Bradford et al., 2009; Das et al., 2012; Kumar et al., 2011; Pradhan et al., 2011; Yang et al., 2014a). Kumar et al. (2011) reported that microbial community structure in soil was adversely affected even at 0.066% of AgNPs (w/w) with reduced recovery of 16S rRNA gene sequences by 44% in comparison to control treatments; whereas, Das et al. (2012) noted a divergence of aquatic bacterial community structure by around 54e56% in comparison to controls at low concentrations (0.01e1 mgL 1) of AgNPs. Yang et al. (2014b) reported a significant reduction of species richness and bacteria involved in nitrification in waste water systems, whereas Pradhan et al., 2011 reported a significant shift in bacterial and fungal community structure in aquatic leaf litter in the presence of AgNPs at 100e300 mg L 1. Although the tested concentrations of AgNPs and the environments were different in these studies, the adverse effects of AgNPs on microbial community structure were evident. These observations were in agreements with our results, where we observed a bacterial community shift in the presence of AgNPs with the emergence of silver tolerant Rhodanobacter sp. An emergence of Rhodanobacter sp. was a notable observation in this study; however, abundance of Rhodanobacter sp. has been reported in uranium and nitrate contaminated sites which correlated with low pH (<4) environments as this species is considered to be an acid tolerant

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: This study showed that AgNPs in their pristine form have adverse effects on microbial growth, functions and diversity in a sandy loam soil, of which effects became more pronounced over time. Microbial growth and activity were affected at the lowest test concentration (49mg kg 1) with estimated IC50s ranging from 19.9 to 173.8 mg kg 1 depending on the test. The impact on microbial diversity was more pronounced in the presence of AgNPs as shown by functional and genomic diversity analyses; however, no concentration-response relationship could be derived due to the semi-quantitative nature of the data. The emergence of Ag-tolerant bacterium was observed in this study at low AgNP concentrations (49e287 mg kg 1) and was isolated and identified as a Rhodanobacter sp. To our knowledge, this is the first study to report the silver tolerance of Rhodanobacter sp. This study also emphasized the usefulness of a battery of microbial toxicity tests with multiple endpoints to assess the eco-toxicological effects of nanoparticles, taking soil microbial functional and structural effects into consideration. This approach may also be useful for the environment risk assessment of nanoparticles.

metadata.abstractText: Silver nano-particles (AgNPs) are widely used in a range of consumer products as a result of their antimicrobial properties. Given the broad spectrum of uses, AgNPs have the potential for being released to the environment. As a result, environmental risks associated with AgNPs need to be assessed to aid in the development of regulatory guidelines. Research was performed to assess the effects of AgNPs on soil microbial activity and diversity in a sandy loam soil with an emphasis on using a battery of microbial tests involving multiple endpoints. The test soil was spiked with PVP coated (0.3%) AgNPs at the following concentrations of 49, 124, 287, 723 and 1815 mg Ag kg 1 dry soil. Test controls included an unamended soil; soil amended with PVP equivalent to the highest PVP concentration of the coated AgNP; and soil amended with humic acid, as 1.8% humic acid was used as a suspension agent for the AgNPs. The impact on soil microbial community was assessed using an array of tests including heterotrophic plate counting, microbial respiration, organic matter decomposition, soil enzyme activity, biological nitrification, community level physiological profiling (CLPP), Ion TorrentTM DNA sequencing and denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE). An impact on microbial growth, activity and community diversity was evident from 49 to 1815 mg kg 1 with the median inhibitory concentrations (IC50) as low as 20 e31 mg kg 1 depending on the test. AgNP showed a notable impact on microbial functional and genomic diversity. Emergence of a silver tolerant bacterium was observed at AgNP concentrations of 49 e287 mg kg 1 after 14e28 days of incubation, but not detectable at 723 and 1815 mg kg 1. The bacterium was identified as Rhodanobacter sp. The study highlighted the effectiveness of using multiple microbial endpoints for inclusion to the environmental risk assessment of nanomaterials.
